Court: While the Court concludes there may be circumstances justifying delay in disclosure of a surveillance tape, the Court finds that Defendant here has not pointed to any justification for delaying disclosure of the tape other than unsupported speculation that the Plaintiff's testimony may be altered in some way to reflect the events on the surveillance tape. The surveillance tape in this case — which the Defendant has submitted and the Court has reviewed — depicts what appears to be a typical slip and fall accident. The tape was not produced by an investigator depicting Plaintiff engaging in activities inconsistent with her claimed injuries. If that was the case there would be a compelling reason to delay disclosure of the tape. Because the tape here depicts the incident giving rise to Plaintiff's claim its primary evidentiary value is proof of the underlying facts surrounding the incident and not primarily for impeachment purposes.

Court: While the Court concludes there may be circumstances justifying delay in disclosure of a surveillance tape, the Court finds that Defendant here has not pointed to any justification for delaying disclosure of the tape other than unsupported speculation that the Plaintiff's testimony may be altered in some way to reflect the events on the surveillance tape. The surveillance tape in this case — which the Defendant has submitted and the Court has reviewed — depicts what appears to be a typical slip and fall accident. The tape was not produced by an investigator depicting Plaintiff engaging in activities inconsistent with her claimed injuries. If that was the case there would be a compelling reason to delay disclosure of the tape. Because the tape here depicts the incident giving rise to Plaintiff's claim its primary evidentiary value is proof of the underlying facts surrounding the incident and not primarily for impeachment purposes.

Court: The undersigned agrees with the Defendant that neither the $35.00 costs of CD depo litigation packages for eight witnesses (ECF No. 326-4 at 3, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18), the $25.00 charge for electronic delivery (ECF No. 326-4 at 6), nor the $1,625.00 for video synchronization (ECF No. 326-4 at 4, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19) are taxable, resulting in a reduction in taxable transcript costs of $1,930.00. Regarding the expedited production costs, identified by the Relators as [*4] totaling $3,257.62 (ECF No. 326 at 7)2, the Relators contend that these costs were reasonably incurred because of the need to refer to these depositions in their motion for summary judgment. The Defendant points out that the deadline for filing motions for summary judgment had been set for more than a year, and two of the expedited depositions were taken after that deadline. The undersigned finds that the need for expedited depositions was created by the Relators themselves, who could have scheduled the depositions in time for ordinary production and delivery. Accordingly, the costs for expediting the depositions is not taxable, resulting in a total award for transcripts of $21,678.43 ($26,866.05 - $1,930.00 - $3,257.62).

Parties: Rule 37 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure authorizes a motion to compel discovery when a party fails to provide proper response to requests for production of documents under Rule 34. Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(a)(3)(B) . "The proponent of a motion to compel discovery ... bears the initial burden of proving that the information sought is relevant." Moore v. Lender Processing Servs. Inc., No. 3:12-CV-205-J, 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 78971 , [2013 BL 147400], 2013 WL 2447948 , at *2 (M.D. Fla. June 5, 2013) (internal quotations omitted) (quoting Diamond State Ins. Co. v. His House, Inc., No. 10-20039-CIV, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 5808 , [2011 BL 420554], 2011 WL 146837 , at *5 (S.D. Fla. Jan. 18, 2011)). The party moving to compel discovery must certify that it "has in good faith conferred or attempted to confer with the person or party failing to make disclosure or discovery in an effort to obtain it without court action." Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(a)(1) . See also M.D. Fla. R. 3.01(g) .
